title: Katt Williams walks on comedy's edge
text:
Katt Williams walks on comedy's edge Donna Isbell Walker , diwalker@greenvillenews.com 2:28 p.m. EDT October 13, 2015 Katt Williams will perform in Greenville 8 p.m. Saturday at Bon Secours Wellness Arena. Katt Williams performs Saturday at Bon Secours Wellness Arena. (Photo: Matt Sayles, AP) 8 CONNECT 3 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
Katt Williams' comedy routines don't shy away from tough topics, and Williams doesn't back away from language that might make listeners uncomfortable. 
He talks about heavy topics like race and politics alongside lighter stories about relationships and TV shows, all of his routines liberally sprinkled with the n-word. 
And despite all of the difficult conversations about race in the culture over the past few years, Williams has no intention of toning down his act or eliminating that particular word. 
"I don't think that a flu virus is properly treated unless there's a flu vaccine, and I think there's a portion of flu that's in the flu vaccine,” Williams said in a recent phone interview. “So the issue is, we don't get to this level of discourse by nitpicking through the conversation. 
“So the conversation has to take place, and the best way for it to take place, especially comedically, is right out front, with all the bits attached, and we just deal with it as it actually is." 
Those conversations will be front and center when Williams brings his "Conspiracy Theory" tour to Bon Secours Wellness Arena Saturday. The tour opened in Columbia earlier this month, and Williams had a purpose in starting the tour in South Carolina. 
Much of the impetus was the massacre of nine African-American church members in Charleston last June, which added another dimension to the national dialogue about race, he said. 
"Once you travel this country, you realize that the things that happen in the inner cities, a lot of those situations are different situations than the things that are taking place in the smaller towns around the U.S.,” he said. “And a lot of the things that people don't know yet, they're already in existence in these pockets in our country that we don't put enough focus on until it's a major news issue.... We understand that this isn't a South conversation, or a Carolina conversation, but it's an actual national conversation." 
Williams, who’s 42, has enjoyed a successful career in standup comedy and in films over the past decade or so. He’s appeared in films like “Norbit” and “Scary Movie 5,” and next year he will co-star with Ed Helms and Owen Wilson in the film “Bastards.” 
For Williams, 42, comedy can be found in every nook and cranny of life, even in the midst of unimaginable tragedy. 
"That's what God created humor to be. Life can be difficult and dangerous and stressful and all of those things, but comedy is the great mediator. No matter how serious the conversations are, there is humor in the discussion. … It's really comedy that allows the discourse to go further than, 'I'm angry, and you're angry’ or ‘I’m sad, and you’re sad.’” 
And Williams doesn’t think that any particular subject should be automatically considered off-limits. Humor, he said, is a way to broach challenging topics in a way that provokes thought and dialogue. 
As he sees it, a comic is like a painter, figuring out where the lines should be. 
"I think the job of the painter is to not go too far, and a part of the process of not going too far is knowing where the lines are. And so the only way that you could know where the lines are, it has to be constantly tested. The painter is always trying to paint something that he hasn't painted before, or figure out a new way to express something that's already been expressed before him.” 
Williams' stage persona is loud, manic, outrageous. Over the phone, however, he's soft-spoken, speaking in thoughtful, measured sentences. 
As with any comic, his stage persona is an amped-up exaggeration of his offstage persona. 
“I'm only given an hour to discuss one million topics with my best friends in the world, and they all gather in one place so we can catch up from we were last time in our conversation, to where we are now so that when we walk out, we feel fulfilled in our relationship,” he said. “It's not something I can do in a calm, lackadaisical fashion... In my personal life, I'm much calmer because I'm a cool, sexy guy.”
